case_title: SETH BANARSI DAS GUPTA vs INCOME TAX OFFICER, MEERUT
complaint_summary: The appellant challenged the disallowance of depreciation on a 1/6th share in S.B. Sugar Mills, Bijnor, and the classification of a Rs. 3,90,750 loss on the sale of shares of Jaswant Sugar Mills Ltd. as a capital loss.
investigation_summary: The Income Tax Tribunal determined that the shares were acquired as investments and not stock-in-trade. The appellant failed to provide evidence to support claims of trade-related transactions.
judgment_summary: The court ruled against the appellant on both questions, affirming that depreciation was not allowable on the 1/6th share in S.B. Sugar Mills, Bijnor, and that the Rs. 3,90,750 loss on the sale of shares was a capital loss. The department was awarded costs of Rs. 200.
punishment: Costs assessed at Rs. 200, counsel's fee also assessed at Rs. 200.
Decision_or_verdict: Questions answered against the assessee and in favor of the department.
legal_arguments: The appellant argued that the shares were stock-in-trade and the loss should be treated as revenue loss.

The appellant relied on precedents such as Investment Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax [1970] 77 ITR 533 (SC) and Raj Kishen Pretn Chandra Jain v. Commissioner of Income-tax [1959] 35 ITR 590 (Punj).
The court found these precedents inapplicable as the appellant's transactions were isolated and not in the nature of trade.
assets: 1/6th share in S.B. Sugar Mills, Bijnor
Shares of Jaswant Sugar Mills Ltd.
key_issues: Depreciation on 1/6th share in S.B. Sugar Mills, Bijnor.
Classification of Rs. 3,90,750 loss on sale of shares as capital loss.

legal_terms.Capital Loss: Loss incurred on the sale of a capital asset.
legal_terms.Depreciation: Reduction in the value of an asset over time.

words_and_phrases.Stock-in-trade: Goods or assets held for sale in the ordinary course of business.
words_and_phrases.Adventure in the nature of trade: A transaction undertaken with the intention of earning profit through trade.

summary_vector_notes: The case involves the disallowance of depreciation on a 1/6th share in S.B. Sugar Mills, Bijnor, and classification of a Rs. 3,90,750 loss on the sale of shares as capital loss. The court ruled against the appellant, affirming the Tribunal's findings that the shares were investments and not stock-in-trade.
